study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and enhance the fidelity of a walking intervention delivered by healthcare providers in general practice, following the NIH Behavior Change Consortium treatment fidelity framework.
results_summary: The study found that 78% of intervention components were delivered as per protocol, with higher fidelity for components requiring active patient engagement. Patient comprehension and engagement were better for volitional planning components than motivational ones aimed at improving self-efficacy.
population_specificity: 63 patients in general practice, with intervention delivered by two practice nurses and six healthcare assistants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate differences in push-off power among different prosthetic ankle-foot units (SACH, ESAR, PWR) and their relation to walking speed in unilateral trans-tibial amputees.
results_summary: The study found significant correlations between walking speed and peak push-off power for ESAR and PWR prosthetics but not for SACH. ESAR and PWR showed significant differences in push-off power at slower and faster walking speeds, suggesting these designs adapt better to varying speeds.
population_specificity: Unilateral trans-tibial amputees using lower limb prostheses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wearable activity trackers could predict hospital-acquired disability (HAD) by measuring physical activity, including walking, in hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The study found that lower physical activity (measured by steps and active time) was associated with HAD, with patients taking fewer steps (1186 vs. 1808 steps/day) and having less active time (0.8 vs. 1.4 h/d) being more likely to develop HAD. The 900 steps/day threshold had poor sensitivity but high specificity for detecting HAD.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60+ admitted to general medicine (n = 46).
study_duration: Median hospital stay of 4 days (IQR = 2.0-6.0 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the correlation between electronic health record documentation of walking, accelerometer-derived physical activity data, and venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis use in hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The study found poor correlation between accelerometer-measured daily steps and documented walking distance in physical therapy/occupational therapy notes. Activity measures were not associated with VTE prophylaxis use or duration, suggesting prophylaxis decisions are not influenced by patient activity levels.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults admitted to general medicine (n = 65).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted intervention, including walking combined with muscle strengthening exercises, in improving osteoarthritis symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the group performing walking exercises (E2) showed significant improvements in joint pain and physical functioning compared to other groups. The intervention led to notable reductions in joint pain and stiffness, as well as enhanced physical functioning.
population_specificity: 90 patients aged 45–82 years with osteoarthritis, recruited from three Community Health Posts.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking combined with muscle strengthening exercises, frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Eight sessions (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review objective clinical measurement methods for assessing walking-related fatigability (WF) across different populations.
results_summary: The study found that longer walking tests, particularly the six-minute walking test (6MWT), were most commonly used to measure WF by comparing changes between the first and last parts of the test. However, no gold standard exists due to variability in tasks and outcome measures across populations, and psychometric properties require further documentation.
population_specificity: Older adults, multiple sclerosis, spinal muscle atrophy, osteoarthritis, interstitial lung diseases, and myasthenia gravis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether workplace interventions to increase standing or walking reduced musculoskeletal symptoms in sedentary workers.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in musculoskeletal symptoms from interventions promoting standing or walking, with low-quality evidence and no long-term benefits observed. A multi-component approach showed a minor reduction in pain-related disability in the medium term, but overall results were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Sedentary workers from high-income countries (955 participants across 10 studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included sit-stand workstations, activity trackers, and multi-component approaches).
study_duration: Short-term (<6 months), medium-term (6-12 months), and long-term (≥12 months) follow-ups were examined, but most data were short-term.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the impact of advanced glaucoma on daily activities, including walking, and exploring treatment options for patients with advanced disease.
results_summary: The abstract notes that glaucoma can impair functionality for daily activities like walking, particularly in patients with severe bilateral visual field loss, but does not provide specific study results on walking.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced open-angle glaucoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on motor features (posture, balance, gait) in depression using instrumental measurements and examine age-related differences.
results_summary: Depression in adults is associated with significant impairments in posture, balance, and gait. Antidepressant drugs and physical exercise may improve motor abnormalities, though high-quality intervention studies are lacking.
population_specificity: Individuals with depressive symptoms or disorders, excluding those with specific physical illnesses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively quantify changes in physical activity (PA) after knee arthroplasty (KA) and compare the effectiveness of GAS-based rehabilitation versus standard rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found a small but significant increase in overall PA (9 minutes/day) and a decrease in sedentary time (20 minutes/day) after KA, but no difference between GAS-based and standard rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients under 65 years of age who underwent total or unicompartmental knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on rehabilitation methods, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments, including cardiorespiratory training (walking), for motor deficits and mood disorders in adults post-stroke.
results_summary: Moderate-quality evidence supported cardiorespiratory training (walking) to improve maximum walking speed in adults post-stroke. Other interventions, such as SSRIs, did not show significant improvements in motor function.
population_specificity: Adults who have had a stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of treadmill gait training combined with conventional physiotherapy on improving spatiotemporal gait parameters in diplegic children.
results_summary: The study found that treadmill gait training alongside conventional treatment significantly improved walking speed, cadence, step length, stride length, and single limb support time in diplegic children compared to conventional treatment alone.
population_specificity: Twenty diplegic children, divided into a control group (conventional treatment) and an experimental group (conventional treatment plus treadmill gait training).

study_goal: The researchers were exploring the role of neutrophil dysfunction in community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and potential therapeutic interventions, not directly studying Walking.
results_summary: The abstract discusses neutrophil dysfunction in older adults and preterm infants, highlighting its impact on infection susceptibility and outcomes, but does not address Walking.
population_specificity: Older adults, children (particularly preterm infants), and individuals with CAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combined aerobic and resistance training on cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle strength, and walking capacity in stroke patients.
results_summary: Exercise training significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle strength, and walking capacity, with optimal effects observed at moderate intensity, 3 days per week, for 20 weeks. Longer training duration and moderate weekly frequency were associated with larger effect sizes.
population_specificity: Adult humans with a history of stroke who ambulate independently.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining sensorimotor training with traditional physical therapy exercises improves joint position sense, pain, muscle endurance, balance, and disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain more effectively than traditional exercises alone.
results_summary: The combined exercise group showed significantly greater improvement in joint position sense, walking speed (10m walk test with head turn), and dynamic balance (step test) compared to the traditional group. Both groups experienced reduced pain and improved muscle endurance and disability, but the combined group had a higher effect on muscle endurance.
population_specificity: 53 patients with chronic non-specific neck pain
study_duration: 4 weeks (assuming 3 sessions per week over 12 sessions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of sarpogrelate hydrochloride compared to conventional treatment for improving symptoms in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Sarpogrelate significantly improved ankle-brachial index, dorsalis pedis artery blood flow, and pain-free walking distance, while also reducing inflammatory markers (hsCRP and IL-6) with good tolerability and no significant adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of foot orthoses versus flat inserts on lower limb biomechanics, knee pain, and confidence in individuals with patellofemoral osteoarthritis (PFOA).
results_summary: Foot orthoses significantly altered peak ankle dorsiflexion angle during level-walking and stair descent in PFOA patients, but the clinical benefits of these changes remain unclear. Knee pain and confidence were also assessed, though specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 21 participants (14 females; mean age 58 ± 8 years) with PFOA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the stress response of the autonomic nervous system (ANS) in individuals with acute and chronic visual impairment (VI) during simulated blindness tasks, including walking.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking's effects, as the study focuses on ANS activity (e.g., heart rate variability) during simulated blindness tasks.
population_specificity: Individuals with normal vision and those with visual impairment (VI) in Rio Branco City, Brazil.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking was part of the task protocol, not a dosage-based intervention).
study_duration: 45 minutes (split into 3 periods of 15 minutes each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of different physiotherapy approaches, including manual therapy, home exercise, and a single session of physiotherapy education, for people with osteoporotic vertebral fractures.
results_summary: At 12 months, there were no significant differences between the groups in quality of life or back muscle endurance. Short-term benefits in endurance, balance, and mobility were observed at 4 months but did not persist.
population_specificity: Adults with back pain, osteoporosis, and at least one osteoporotic vertebral fracture (n=615).
effective_dosage: 7 individual physiotherapy sessions over 12 weeks (manual therapy or home exercise) compared to a single session of physiotherapy education.
study_duration: 12 weeks (intervention), with follow-up at 4 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare foot/ankle kinematics and kinetics in patients with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction (PTTD) versus healthy controls during gait.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found increased dorsiflexion and abduction in the forefoot, as well as increased plantarflexion and eversion in the hindfoot during stance in PTTD patients, suggesting altered gait mechanics associated with the condition.
population_specificity: Patients with posterior tibial tendon dysfunction (PTTD) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers sought to assess and describe tendon pain in recreational runners with Achilles tendinopathy using multidimensional pain scales (sf-MPQ and sf-BPI) alongside the VISA-A questionnaire.
results_summary: Tendon pain was primarily sensory (e.g., aching, tender, throbbing) and interfered with mood, walking ability, sleep, and enjoyment of life, suggesting AT may have clinical subtypes beyond physical impairment.
population_specificity: 124 recreational runners with mid-portion Achilles tendinopathy for at least 3 months, recruited from Cape Town, South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a novel delivery scheme involving walking times as a factor in adherence to iron supplementation in highly isolated indigenous communities.
results_summary: Walking times were found to influence adherence, with higher adherence linked to shorter walking times. The intervention significantly reduced anemia by 48.2% and iron-deficient anemia by 67.7% in the supplementation group.
population_specificity: Indigenous Tarahumara communities in Mexico, specifically children and women with anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate functional goal achievement (using goal attainment scaling) following lower limb BoNT-A injection for poststroke spasticity, focusing on mobility and positioning improvements.
results_summary: The study found that 88.3% of patients achieved their primary treatment goals, with 87.0% success in mobility and 100.0% in positioning. Functional scales showed improvements, including a slight increase in walking speed.
population_specificity: Adults with poststroke lower limb spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lower-body positive pressure on surface blood flow during standing and treadmill walking to assess cardiovascular safety for rehabilitation applications.
results_summary: Lower-body positive pressure decreased blood flow in the forehead and thigh during walking but increased it during standing. The extent of blood flow changes during walking onset decreased with higher applied pressure, suggesting the apparatus modulates blood flow safely for rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 13 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of nusinersen in presymptomatic infants with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) regarding motor function outcomes, including walking.
results_summary: All 25 participants achieved sitting without support, 92% achieved walking with assistance, and 88% achieved independent walking. No participants required permanent ventilation, though 16% with two SMN2 copies needed temporary respiratory support during acute illnesses.
population_specificity: 25 presymptomatic infants with genetically diagnosed SMA (15 with two SMN2 copies, 10 with three SMN2 copies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised, progressive treadmill walking exercise (TMWX) training improves cognitive processing speed (CPS) and brain functioning in fully-ambulatory persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) who exhibit slowed CPS.
results_summary: The study proposes that 12 weeks of TMWX training may improve CPS and thalamocortical brain connectivity compared to an active control condition involving stretching-and-resistance exercise, with additional exploratory benefits for community participation, daily living, quality of life, and functional mobility.
population_specificity: Fully-ambulatory persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) who present with slowed cognitive processing speed (CPS).
effective_dosage: Initially 15 minutes of light-to-moderate intensity TMWX, progressing to 40 minutes of vigorous intensity TMWX, 3 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether exercise (including walking) could influence inflammation and disability in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found small decreases in inflammatory markers (IL-17 and IFN-γ) after exercise, along with improvements in functional outcomes and perceived disability status, though these improvements may not be directly linked to changes in cytokine levels.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate effects of kinesiology taping (KT) on pain reduction and gait function in older adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: KT significantly improved gait and balance while reducing knee pain during walking compared to non-KT conditions (P < .05). The study concluded that KT positively affects pain reduction and walking/balance ability in older adults with OA.
population_specificity: Older adults (n=10) living in the community with diagnosed knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of single auditory-cued stepping in place (SIP) training on cortical excitability, rhythmic movements, and walking ability in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Auditory-cued SIP training improved lower-limb movement variability, modulated cortical excitability, and increased walking cadence in patients with Parkinson's disease, with freezers potentially benefiting more than nonfreezers.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD), including freezers and nonfreezers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions involved SIP with and without auditory cues).
study_duration: Each participant completed two interventions with at least a one-week washout period in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pain neuroscience education (PNE) combined with rehabilitation could improve walking pain and psychological outcomes in hospitalized patients after high tibial osteotomy (HTO) for knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that PNE combined with rehabilitation slightly reduced pain catastrophizing compared to rehabilitation alone, with a small effect size (d = 0.44). Rehabilitation itself significantly decreased catastrophizing, but the additional benefit of PNE was modest.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥45 years with knee osteoarthritis scheduled for HTO and with a Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS) score ≥21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current and new perspectives on measuring skeletal muscle function in COPD patients, including walking capacity.
results_summary: The study highlights the need for standardized measurement protocols for skeletal muscle function in COPD, emphasizing dynamic measurements like walking capacity, which relate more to daily living tasks than static measurements. It also notes that functional tests and muscle function measurements evaluate different constructs and should not replace each other.
population_specificity: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients with skeletal muscle dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Nordic walking (NW) versus regular walking (W) combined with diet on body composition, aerobic capacity, and strength in overweight adults over a 6-month period.
results_summary: Both NW and W groups showed significant reductions in BMI and waist circumference after 6 months, but only the NW group demonstrated additional benefits in body composition and aerobic capacity. The study concluded that NW may offer greater and faster health improvements compared to W for overweight middle-aged adults.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (mean age 66 years, BMI 32-33)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how arm swing asymmetry in early Parkinson's disease (PD) relates to gait parameters, particularly shoulder and elbow motions, compared to controls.
results_summary: The study found that PD patients exhibited increased arm swing asymmetry at the wrist compared to controls, with elbow range of motion (RoM) asymmetry being a significant predictor and mediator of this effect. The interaction between PD status and elbow RoM asymmetry indicated that PD modifies the relationship between elbow motion and arm swing asymmetry.
population_specificity: 41 early-stage Parkinson's disease patients and 23 healthy controls.
study_duration: Single session (3D motion analysis during walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intermittent vacuum therapy (IVT) provided additional benefits to supervised exercise therapy (SET) for improving walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The study found no additional benefit of IVT over SET alone, with both groups showing similar improvements in walking distance, ambulatory ability, and quality of life. The differences between the intervention and control groups were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: IC patients recruited from three Dutch general hospitals.
effective_dosage: IVT was administered at -50 mBar negative pressure for 30 minutes per session, 12 sessions over 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Nordic walking training (NW) and multicomponent training (MCT) on cognitive processes, cardiovascular fitness, and motor fitness in older adults.
results_summary: Both NW and MCT improved cardiovascular and motor fitness, with NW showing better results in the 30 Seconds Chair Stand test and MCT in the One Leg Stance test. Cognitive improvements (executive functions, spatial memory, and processing speed) were observed with no significant difference between the two training methods.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (mean age 70.8 years, 17 males, 22 females).
effective_dosage: 3 times/week, supervised sessions with heart rate monitoring to ensure equivalent intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two types of aerobic walking training (with and without a lower limb load) on muscle metabolism in adults with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Both training groups showed a reduction in relative time to recovery, improved re-oxygenation rate, and increased resistance time after reaching the lowest muscle oxygen saturation. The study suggests that walking, with or without a load, can positively impact muscle metabolism in PAD patients.
population_specificity: Adults with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of a novel paclitaxel-coated drug-coated balloon (DCB) versus uncoated plain old balloon angioplasty (POBA) in improving walking and reducing restenosis in patients with femoropopliteal artery disease.
results_summary: The novel DCB significantly reduced late lumen loss and improved walking compared to POBA, with 44.6-50% of DCB patients showing improved Rutherford-Becker classification stages. DCB also demonstrated higher primary patency (90.3% vs. 65.3%) and lower target lesion revascularization (1.3% vs. 18.7%) at 12 months.
population_specificity: 171 patients with stenotic and occlusive lesions of the femoropopliteal artery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the short-term effects of HBO2 therapy on pain reduction and the long-term effects on return-to-play time in athletes with grade 2 MCL knee injuries.
results_summary: HBO2 therapy significantly reduced pain scores during walking and jogging and accelerated return to play compared to the non-HBO2 group.
population_specificity: Japanese professional or semi-professional rugby players with grade 2 MCL knee injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and preliminary impact of a pedometer-based intervention on physical activity, symptoms, and cardiovascular risk surrogates in dialysis patients.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased daily step counts and heart rate variability but did not improve symptoms, physical performance, or endothelial function. Step counts reverted to baseline post-intervention.
population_specificity: 60 dialysis patients from San Francisco dialysis clinics.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer-based with weekly step goals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of conservative treatment, percutaneous surgery, and open surgery for acute Achilles tendon rupture, all followed by early weightbearing rehabilitation.
results_summary: At 1-year follow-up, all treatments showed similar efficacy, with 100% success in conservative treatment, 82% in percutaneous surgery, and 83% in open surgery. No total reruptures were reported.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥18 years with acute Achilles tendon rupture (median age 41, 94% male).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment methods, not dosage, were compared).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether technology-assisted gait training (TAGT) with body weight support (BWS) is superior to conventional overground training (COT) for improving post-stroke walking disability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between TAGT and COT across all outcome categories, including motor impairment, mobility, walking speed, endurance, balance, and daily living activities, both in the short and long term. Subgroup analyses also showed non-significant results for initial ambulatory ability and stroke duration.
population_specificity: Patients within 6 months after stroke (subacute stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dynamic and static orthoses on hallux valgus angle, range of motion, and patient satisfaction during walking.
results_summary: Both static and dynamic orthoses significantly reduced the hallux valgus angle by 2-3°, with the dynamic orthosis also improving the passive range of motion. No significant difference was found in overall patient-reported outcomes (FAOS score).
population_specificity: 24 participants with mild to moderate hallux valgus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-intensity (twice weekly) versus high-intensity (10 times weekly) treadmill training on walking attainment and overall walking activity in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: No significant differences were found between the two intensity groups in any outcome measure. The low-intensity group showed significant improvement in one measure (GMFM E) immediately post-intervention, while the high-intensity group demonstrated better walking independence on the Functional Mobility Scale at all post-intervention assessments. Both dosages were equally effective in improving walking-related skills.
population_specificity: Children (ages 14-32 months) with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy, Gross Motor Function Classification System Level I and II.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether augmenting cholinergic neurotransmission with donepezil improves static and dynamic balance in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in static or dynamic balance measures between donepezil and placebo, indicating that donepezil did not improve balance in PD patients. Secondary measures also showed no significant effects, except for one static balance measure that was slightly increased by donepezil.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (n=45 completed the trial).
effective_dosage: 5 mg/day for 3 weeks, then increased to 10 mg/day for the remaining 3 weeks.
study_duration: 6 weeks per treatment period, with a 6-week washout between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Cartiva synthetic cartilage implants (SCI) versus osteotomies for treating conditions affecting the second metatarsal head, focusing on patient-reported outcomes.
results_summary: Cartiva SCI showed modest improvements in MOXFQ and FAAM scores, but 4 of 6 patients required revisions to osteotomies. Osteotomies demonstrated better functional outcomes, with significant improvements in MOXFQ and FAAM scores.
population_specificity: Female patients with symptomatic conditions affecting the second metatarsal head (e.g., Freiberg's disease, osteochondral defects).
study_duration: Average follow-up of 19 months for Cartiva SCI and 27 months for osteotomies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine health utilities in COPD patients and identify variables impacting their quality of life, including self-reported daily walking time.
results_summary: The study found a linear relationship between self-reported daily walking time and EQ-5D utility, indicating better quality of life with more walking. However, walking was not the primary focus, and its direct efficacy was not isolated from other variables.
population_specificity: Stable COPD patients from 4 observational studies (n=6,198).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether branched-chain amino acid supplementation (BCAAem) improves cognitive performance, muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in elderly malnourished patients compared to diet advice alone.
results_summary: BCAAem supplementation was more effective than diet advice in improving cognitive performance (MMSE), mitochondrial function (ATP production, electron flux), and maintaining low oxidative stress, while both groups showed improvements in nutritional status, muscle mass, strength, and physical performance.
population_specificity: 155 elderly malnourished patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the presence of abnormal cortisol responses due to abnormal receptors in subjects with ACTH-independent Cushing's Syndrome (AICS) and nodular adrenal hyperplasia, particularly focusing on the postural walking test.
results_summary: The study found that 58.3% of cases showed positivity in the postural walking test, indicating abnormal cortisol responses. Bilateral or unilateral adrenalectomy was performed in some cases, while others remained under observation.
population_specificity: 15 cases (13 female, mean age 56.8 years) diagnosed with AICS and nodular adrenal hyperplasia.
study_duration: Study period spanned 14 years (2002-2016), but intervention duration per case is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the type and duration of physical activity, including walking, performed by hospitalized adults to assess inactivity levels and establish benchmarks for inpatient mobility practices.
results_summary: The study found that hospitalized patients spent 87-100% of their time sitting or lying in bed, with medical inpatients spending an average of 70 minutes per day standing or walking. The review highlighted substantial inactivity during hospitalization and the need for standardized mobility measurement methods.
population_specificity: Adult acute-care inpatients, including geriatric, surgical, medical, post-stroke, psychiatric, and critical care patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of an exercise and nursing education health informatics program (which included walking as part of exercise capacity assessment) on quality of life, exercise capacity, and nutrition in post-esophagectomy patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in exercise capacity (measured via the six-minute walking test and maximal oxygen uptake) and quality of life compared to the control group, with notable benefits in physical, emotional, and social functioning.
population_specificity: Patients who had undergone esophagectomy for esophageal cancer in a medical center in Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking was part of broader exercise capacity assessment).
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed at baseline, 1, 3, and 6 months post-discharge.

study_goal: To determine if MEMS inertial sensors are as accurate as fiber-optic gyroscopes for classifying balance during clinical stance and gait tasks.
results_summary: MEMS sensors provided measurements comparable to fiber-optic gyroscopes for assessing balance during stance and gait tasks. Angle and angular velocity measures were recommended for stance, while only angular velocity measures were recommended for gait due to minimal influence from yaw rotations.
population_specificity: Ten healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a lung ultrasound-guided follow-up protocol improves outcomes, including walking capacity, in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: The LUS-guided follow-up reduced urgent visits for worsening heart failure and improved walking capacity, as measured by the 6-minute walking test, with an increase of 60 meters compared to 37 meters in the control group.
population_specificity: 123 patients admitted for heart failure (mean age 69 ± 12 years, 72% male, mean left ventricular ejection fraction 39 ± 14%).
study_duration: 180 days (follow-up visits at 14, 30, 90, and 180 days after discharge)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify differences in timed 25-foot walk (T25FW) performance between individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and controls without MS, as well as between different disability statuses and clinical disease courses within MS.
results_summary: The study found large differences in T25FW performance, with MS patients walking significantly slower than controls (mean difference=2.4s), moderate/severe disability patients slower than mild disability (mean difference=5.4s), and progressive MS patients slower than relapsing-remitting MS (mean difference=13.4s). All differences were statistically significant (P<.01).
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and controls without MS, categorized by disability status (mild, moderate/severe) and clinical disease course (relapsing-remitting, progressive).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) levels and disease severity/treatment outcome in idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) patients, using the six-minute walking test (6MWT) as one of the measures.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in FeNO levels between IPAH patients and controls, and FeNO levels did not correlate with disease severity or treatment response. However, other markers (e.g., BNP, functional class) showed correlations with treatment effects over three months.
population_specificity: 36 IPAH patients (29 women, 7 men, mean age 38.4 ± 11.3 years) and 30 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in physical activity, particularly walking, as part of a cardiovascular disease risk reduction intervention for women in rural communities.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a statistically significant increase in walking MET minutes per week compared to the control group, though accelerometry data did not reveal significant between-group differences in overall physical activity.
population_specificity: Sedentary women aged 40 and older with overweight and obesity living in rural communities.
effective_dosage: Twice weekly exercise classes (48 total sessions over 24 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of exercise (specifically walking) on muscle perfusion and its association with pain relief in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that a 12-week supervised exercise program significantly improved muscle perfusion and reduced pain in knee OA patients, though no significant changes were observed in muscle strength or function. Changes in pain and muscle perfusion were correlated, but mediation by perfusion changes was unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (n=33, with 16 in the exercise group and 17 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise therapy 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between family support and outcomes for families and children affected by disability in low- and middle-income countries, including the impact of movement and mobility therapy on children's walking patterns.
results_summary: Movement and mobility therapy provided by rehabilitation professionals improved children's walking patterns. Positive community attitudes facilitated social participation for children with disabilities.
population_specificity: Families and children affected by disability in low- and middle-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of a six-week inspiratory resistance training (IRT) on metabolic health biomarkers, pulmonary function, and endurance in obese individuals.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention.
population_specificity: Obese adults (BMI > 27 kg/m²)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether visual feedback training with visual targets improves muscle activity, balance, and gait in hemiplegic stroke patients compared to visual feedback training alone.
results_summary: The experimental group (visual feedback with visual targets) showed significantly larger gains in gluteus medius muscle activation and paretic-side weight-bearing ability compared to the control group (visual feedback alone). The findings suggest that visual targets enhance the effectiveness of visual feedback training for stroke rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Hemiplegic stroke patients from an inpatient rehabilitation hospital.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of visual feedback training (with or without visual targets), three sets per day, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect and dose-response of pre-surgery physiotherapy on quadriceps femoris strength and walking ability in patients with degenerative lumbar spine disorders compared to waiting-list controls.
results_summary: Pre-surgery physiotherapy significantly improved walking ability, lower extremity strength, and physical activity levels compared to waiting-list controls, with no clear dose-response relationship. The improvements were maintained post-surgery, with pre-surgery physical activity level being a significant predictor of postoperative activity.
population_specificity: Patients aged 25-80 years with MRI-confirmed degenerative lumbar spine disorders (disc herniation, lumbar spinal stenosis, degenerative disc disease, or spondylolisthesis) scheduled for surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased movement variability in walking indicates pathological performance by comparing healthy and pathological motor behavior.
results_summary: The study identified optimal thresholds of variability in 7 spatio-temporal parameters, showing that pathology generally increased variability except in step width. Stride time variability was qualified as a movement biomarker for clinical trials.
population_specificity: 2409 patients and 2523 healthy asymptomatic controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate nonpharmacologic approaches, including walking, as part of dementia management.
results_summary: The study suggests that physical exercise such as walking may benefit patients with dementia, though the efficacy of available treatments, including nonpharmacologic approaches, remains limited.
population_specificity: Patients with dementia, particularly Alzheimer disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mobilization with movement (MWM) on function and pain in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to a sham procedure.
results_summary: MWM significantly improved pain, pressure pain threshold, walking function (TUG test), knee strength, and knee flexion range of motion immediately and 2 days post-intervention compared to sham MWM, but showed no significant effect on WOMAC scores or knee extension ROM.
population_specificity: Adult patients with knee osteoarthritis of grade II and above.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the complications of unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA), specifically tibial plateau fractures, and their treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study reported two cases of tibial plateau fractures post-UKA, treated with surgical fixation and conservative methods, both showing good outcomes after one year with no pain or prosthesis loosening.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (70 and 72 years old) who underwent UKA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and radiological outcomes of surgical treatment for tibial metastasis and identify specific risks associated with this condition.
results_summary: The study found that surgical outcomes were comparable to existing literature, with notable risks of infection and benefits of preventative fixation. Adverse events included surgical site infections, pulmonary embolism, and cardiac rhythm disturbances.
population_specificity: 25 patients (15 men, 10 women) with tibial metastasis, mean age 66±11.7 years, primarily with kidney or lung cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of gait training using a wearable hip-assist robot (GEMS) on locomotor function and efficiency in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significantly greater improvement in spatiotemporal gait parameters and muscle efforts compared to the control group after the training intervention.
population_specificity: 26 patients with chronic stroke and hemiparesis.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions (5 treadmill, 5 over-ground gait training) with GEMS.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over the course of 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a modified cerclage wiring technique for treating comminuted patellar fractures.
results_summary: The study found that modified cerclage wiring effectively treated comminuted patellar fractures, with no postoperative complications observed and satisfactory clinical results (84.2% excellent, 15.8% good outcomes). Patients achieved active flexion of 130° on average.
population_specificity: 38 patients (16 males, 22 females) aged 23-68 years with unilateral closed comminuted patellar fractures (AO/OTA types 34-C2 and 34-C3).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical technique, not a supplement).

study_goal: To summarize the evidence on the effects of prolonged-release fampridine on walking disability in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: PR fampridine showed significant benefits for walking short distances and perceived walking capacity, but no significant effects on muscle strength, middle-distance walking, higher-level cognitive functions, or hand and arm use.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (2616 participants across 20 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of vibration therapy (VT) could improve muscular and functional performance in individuals with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: VT significantly improved repeated chair rises, timed up-and-go test, and 6-minute walk test compared to control, with meaningful changes in walking performance and delayed onset of claudication.
population_specificity: Fourteen PAD participants with intermittent claudication (mean age 73.9 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (single session of VT during functional testing).
study_duration: Single session (each intervention separated by at least 2 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of stepping training with or without external feedback on lower limb support ability and functional independence in individuals with stroke.
results_summary: Participants showed significant improvement in lower limb support ability immediately after the first training with external feedback, with further improvements in support ability, duration, and Timed Up and Go performance after 2 and 4 weeks of training. No such improvements were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with stroke who could walk independently for at least 10 meters, with or without walking devices.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of stepping training (with or without feedback) followed by 10 minutes of overground walking, 5 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cilostazol on walking distance and calf pain severity in patients with Dry Eye Syndrome (DES).
results_summary: The study found that cilostazol significantly improved walking distance (p<0.05) and reduced calf pain severity (p<0.005) compared to the placebo group. Treated patients also showed improvement in calf pain severity (p<0.03).
population_specificity: 80 subjects (40 treated with cilostazol, 40 untreated) with Dry Eye Syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore patient goals, including walking, as part of individualized rehabilitation for chronic pain patients undergoing spinal cord stimulation.
results_summary: Walking was one of the highest-ranked goals in the domain of activities for patients with chronic pain, indicating its perceived importance for improving function and quality of life. The study highlighted the need for personalized rehabilitation approaches to address such goals.
population_specificity: Fifteen patients with failed back/neck surgery syndrome scheduled for spinal cord stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of wearable technology for automating walking tests and enhancing rehabilitation in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that wearable devices could standardize walking tests, reduce costs, and improve gait rehabilitation efficacy. The Ambulosono platform, combining brisk walking with motivational strategies, showed potential to slow PD progression and make walking a pleasurable habit.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the factors influencing functional outcomes of locomotor training and summarize the mechanisms underlying its role in neuroplasticity and functional recovery after spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Locomotor training, including body-weight-supported walking, improves locomotor function in individuals with incomplete SCI, with effectiveness depending on injury severity and time post-injury. For chronic and motor complete SCI, additional interventions like epidural stimulation may enhance recovery.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI), particularly incomplete SCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intradialytic aerobic exercise with blood flow restriction, conventional exercise, and no exercise on muscle strength and walking endurance in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: Intradialytic exercise with blood flow restriction improved walking endurance more effectively than conventional exercise or no exercise. Muscle strength was also measured, but the abstract does not specify the results for this outcome.
population_specificity: Adult chronic kidney disease patients on hemodialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and acceptability of milk consumption combined with resistance exercise to improve muscle function in older adults at risk of sarcopenia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention, as it is a pilot study focused on feasibility and acceptability rather than efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged ≥65 years at risk of sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: 500 mL of whole or skimmed milk (~20 g of protein) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the effects of two types of knee sleeves on knee adduction moment, pain, stiffness, and physical function in patients with early knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both knee sleeves significantly reduced pain, knee adduction moment during early and late stance, and increased walking speed after 6 weeks of use, with no additional benefits from the patella cutout sleeve.
population_specificity: 17 participants with early unilateral knee osteoarthritis (mean age 47.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of physical therapy and complementary exercises, including various forms of walking, in improving motor performance and functional mobility in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that gait training with treadmill, Nordic walking, brisk walking, and other exercises improved walking performance, balance, and reduced fall rates, with some benefits lasting 3-12 months. Sustained interventions like Tai Chi and dance therapy showed potential to slow PD progression.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease.
study_duration: Varied by intervention (e.g., 3-6 months for treadmill training, 12 months for dance therapy, 24 months for progressive resistive training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of task-oriented (OTM) and impairment-based (STD) exercise interventions on standing balance and lower extremity muscle strength in older adults.
results_summary: The OTM group showed significant reductions in sway acceleration during most balance conditions, while the STD group had smaller, nonsignificant reductions. Both exercise groups improved strength compared to the waitlist control, with no significant difference between the two interventions.
population_specificity: 107 older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of structured walking interventions and calf muscle activity in improving patient-centered outcomes for individuals with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that structured walking interventions or those increasing calf muscle activity improved walking, quality of life, and pain reduction, particularly when administered before PAD became severe. Severe PAD cases showed more frequent improvements in amputation incidence and ulcer healing, often in response to invasive interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including those with varying severity levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the associations between opioid doses on post-operative day 1 (POD1) and pain/function outcomes, specifically gait distance, in patients following lumbar spine surgery (LSS).
results_summary: The study found that higher opioid doses on POD1 did not result in better pain control or improved gait distance compared to medium or low doses. Patients in medium and low dose groups walked greater distances on POD2 and POD3, though differences did not reach adjusted statistical significance.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent lumbar spine surgery (LSS) between January 2007 and March 2018.
effective_dosage: High dose (168.75 ± 69.50 mg OME), medium dose (65.92 ± 13.28 mg OME), low dose (16.90 ± 9.80 mg OME) on POD1.
study_duration: Assessed outcomes up to post-operative day 3 (POD3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify gait abnormalities in individuals with Dravet syndrome (DS) and identify distinct gait patterns.
results_summary: The study identified two gait patterns in DS: an atypical crouch gait with increased joint flexion and reduced walking speed, and a pattern resembling healthy controls but still with reduced speed and stride length. No differences in clinical or anamnestic data were found between the groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with a confirmed diagnosis of Dravet syndrome (mean age 13.8 ± 7.3 years; 26 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess ward-based walking patterns in adults hospitalized with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and determine if daily step count influenced length of stay (LOS).
results_summary: The study found that hospitalized CAP patients walked very little, mostly in short bouts at low intensity. Higher daily step counts were associated with an 11% reduction in LOS per 500 steps, while moderate to severe frailty correlated with 59% fewer steps.
population_specificity: Adults hospitalized with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).
effective_dosage: Not specified (step count monitored, not prescribed).
study_duration: Monitoring occurred during hospitalization (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the predictive accuracy of five geriatric health indicators, including walking speed, for mortality, hospitalizations, and healthcare contacts among older adults.
results_summary: Walking speed (WS) showed high accuracy in predicting 3-year and 5-year mortality (AUC 0.85), comparable to other comprehensive indicators like the frailty index and Health Assessment Tool. However, it was less predictive of unplanned hospitalizations and healthcare contacts compared to other indicators.
population_specificity: 3,363 individuals aged 60+ from the Swedish National Study on Aging and Care in Kungsholmen.
study_duration: Not specified (predictive accuracy assessed over 3-year and 5-year periods)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes, including survival, adverse events, and functional improvements (such as 6MWT), of bosentan and macitentan in CTEPH patients over a 2-year follow-up.
results_summary: Both drugs showed improved clinical outcomes, including WHO FC, NT-proBNP levels, and 6MWT distance, with no significant differences between them. Survival and clinical worsening rates were numerically better for bosentan but not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) patients who were technically inoperable or had residual CTEPH (58% female, mean age 62 ± 14 years, 68% WHO FC III/IV).
study_duration: Mean treatment duration was 1.9 ± 0.4 years for bosentan and 1.2 ± 0.6 years for macitentan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review interventions promoting functional mobility (walking and moving around) for individuals with Machado-Joseph disease (MJD) and align them with the 'Staying Strong' Framework described by Aboriginal families.
results_summary: The review identified 30 studies, with most interventions aligning with physical ('exercising your body') and medical ('searching for good medicine') domains of the framework, but few addressed psychosocial domains ('having something important to do,' 'keeping yourself happy'). No studies aligned with cultural or familial domains ('going country,' 'families helping each other').
population_specificity: Adolescents and adults with Machado-Joseph disease (MJD), particularly from Aboriginal communities in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of high-intensity exercise on walking competency in individuals with stroke.
results_summary: The study found that high-intensity exercise significantly improved walking distance, comfortable gait speed, stride length, and Time Up&Go (TUG) performance compared to low-to-moderate intensity exercise or usual physical activities. The results were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Individuals with stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of a fixed combination of cinnarizine and dimenhydrinate versus betahistine in treating vertigo derived from peripheral vestibular disorders.
results_summary: The fixed combination of cinnarizine/dimenhydrinate was superior to betahistine in reducing vertigo symptoms and received more favorable ratings for overall efficacy and daily activity impairment. Both treatments were well tolerated, with few adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Outpatients with peripheral vestibular vertigo from ENT clinics in Austria, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, and Russia (mean age 53.5 years, ~60% female).
effective_dosage: Cinnarizine 20 mg/dimenhydrinate 40 mg or betahistine dihydrochloride 16 mg, three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term effects of noninvasive brain stimulation (NIBS) on functional balance and postural control in stroke patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant positive effects of NIBS, particularly repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), on functional balance and postural control in stroke patients, with more sessions correlating to greater improvements. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) did not show significant therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Patients with acute, subacute, and chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: Not specified (number of rTMS sessions was a significant moderator but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term effects assessed, but exact duration not detailed).

study_goal: To determine the effect of taurine supplementation on sweating and core temperature responses during prolonged low-intensity exercise with fixed-heat production.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation significantly increased sweating responses (WBSL, LSR, SGA) and enhanced evaporative heat loss while reducing heat storage during exercise.
population_specificity: 15 participants (3 females, 12 males; 27 ± 5 years, 78 ± 9 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fixed-flow versus automated oxygen delivery during walking tests in patients with chronic respiratory diseases.
results_summary: The study found that automated oxygen delivery improved walking endurance and reduced oxygen desaturation compared to fixed-flow oxygen in patients with chronic respiratory diseases.
population_specificity: Subjects with chronic respiratory diseases (COPD, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary hypertension, cystic fibrosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether visible greenspaces in hospitals improve wayfinding performance and enhance mood and spatial experience during walking navigation.
results_summary: Participants performed better in wayfinding tasks (less time, shorter distance, fewer stops) and reported improved mood and spatial experience in hospital environments with visible greenspaces compared to those without.
population_specificity: 74 participants randomly assigned to experimental groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of nutrition supplements on rehabilitation outcomes, including walking ability, for stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of nutrition supplements on functional outcomes, disabilities, or complications, but noted improvements in activities of daily living (ADL) and reduced infection incidence. Walking ability was not significantly impacted.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (7,547 patients across 16 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an exercise program (including Nordic walking) alone or combined with omega-3 supplementation improved short-term episodic memory and BDNF levels in elderly women.
results_summary: The exercise program significantly improved short-term memory, but omega-3 supplementation provided no additional benefit. BDNF levels remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: 55 healthy elderly women aged 65-80 years.
effective_dosage: Functional circuit training twice a week and Nordic walking once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nutritional supplementation combined with exercise training on frailty characteristics, including walking speed, in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that combined interventions improved walking speed (mean difference: 0.09 m/s) and other physical function measures, though effects on body weight, fatigue, and quality of life were uncertain. Results should be interpreted cautiously due to study heterogeneity and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pursed-lip breathing (PLB) while using a portable oxygen concentrator (POC) during walking in patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD).
results_summary: The study found that acute exposure to PLB did not improve symptoms, muscle oxygenation, or SpO2 in ILD patients during walking. No significant benefits were observed compared to natural breathing.
population_specificity: Patients with interstitial lung disease (ILD), including those with exercise-induced desaturation (EID) and normal SpO2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and utility of a mobile smartphone application (Heart Coach) for improving participation and adherence in cardiac rehabilitation, including walking as part of the daily task list.
results_summary: Patients engaged with the app 90% of days, reporting high compliance and adherence, with 83% rating their experience as positive/very positive. Providers noted improved communication, clinical insight, and program efficiency.
population_specificity: Twenty-six patients enrolled in cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking was part of a daily "task list").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of vitamin D alone or combined with protein supplementation on muscle strength, mass, and performance in patients with sarcopenia.
results_summary: Vitamin D plus protein supplementation improved muscle strength (handgrip strength) but had no effect on muscle mass or performance in sarcopenia patients.
population_specificity: Patients with sarcopenia
effective_dosage: Vitamin D (100-1600 IU/day) plus protein (10-44 g/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if home-based 6-minute walk tests (6MWT) and passively collected activity data could supplement or replace in-clinic 6MWTs for monitoring frailty and functional capacity in cardiovascular disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that smartphone and Apple Watch data accurately predicted frailty (90% sensitivity, 85% specificity in-clinic; 83% sensitivity, 60% specificity at home). Passive data was nearly as accurate as home-based 6MWTs for predicting frailty (AUC 0.643 vs. 0.704).
population_specificity: 110 participants scheduled for vascular or cardiac procedures.
effective_dosage: Weekly at-home 6MWTs via the VascTrac app; passive daily step count monitoring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) on spasticity, balance, and walking speed in stroke patients.
results_summary: TENS significantly reduced spasticity (measured by MAS), improved static balance (both open and closed eyes), and increased walking speed, but did not affect dynamic balance (Timed Up and Go Test).
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reproducibility and acceptability of the two-chair test (2CT) as a space-efficient alternative to the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) for assessing post-exercise changes in pulse rate and oxygen saturation.
results_summary: The study found that the 2CT was reproducible and comparable to the 6MWT in terms of its impact on pulse rate and oxygen saturation, suggesting it as a viable alternative for small spaces. The test showed consistent results across two volunteer groups.
population_specificity: 40 and 60 volunteers (total 100) for reproducibility and acceptability testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify associations between built environment supports (e.g., sidewalks) and destinations (e.g., shops) with walking behaviors among urban- and rural-dwelling adults.
results_summary: The study found that specific environmental elements (e.g., sidewalks, relaxing destinations) were associated with leisure and transportation walking, with walking prevalence increasing as more supportive elements were reported. Associations varied by urban/rural residence.
population_specificity: Nationally-representative sample of 29,925 urban- and rural-dwelling adults from the 2015 National Health Interview Survey.
study_duration: Past-week walking behavior was assessed (cross-sectional study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised exercise training accelerates the return to baseline walking ability compared to unsupervised training in cancer patients undergoing colorectal surgery.
results_summary: Supervised exercise training significantly improved functional capacity and muscle strength, with patients having over two times higher chances of returning to baseline walking ability post-surgery. Supervised pre-habilitation showed the strongest effects (OR = 7.71 at 4 weeks and OR = 8.62 at 8 weeks).
population_specificity: Cancer patients scheduled for colorectal surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise sessions were supervised but exact frequency/duration not detailed).
study_duration: Assessed at baseline, before surgery, and at 4 and 8 weeks after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of 5-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) with sodium ferrous citrate (SFC) supplementation during home-based walking training in middle-aged women with major depressive disorder.
results_summary: The study used a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind crossover design to evaluate interval walking training (IWT) with ALA + SFC versus placebo. Results indicated that exercise intensity was measured by accelerometry, and lactate concentration in plasma was assessed before and after each trial, but specific efficacy outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Middle-aged women (53 ± 8 years) with major depressive disorder.
study_duration: Two 7-day trials with a >10-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the factors influencing the acute effect of supplemental oxygen during exercise (6-minute walk test) in patients with COPD.
results_summary: Oxygen supplementation increased the 6-minute walk distance in patients with COPD, particularly in subgroups with hypoxemia (HYX) and exercise-induced hypoxemia (EIH), but not in those without hypoxemia (NOX). Less than half of patients achieved clinically relevant improvements, with responders characterized by lower baseline exercise capacity.
population_specificity: 124 patients with COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of neuromuscular scoliosis (NMS) on walking and other functions, and to discuss management strategies including surgical and non-operative approaches.
results_summary: The study found that progressive spinal deformity in NMS causes difficulty with walking, among other functional impairments, and that surgical management is associated with good long-term outcomes and high satisfaction rates. Non-operative management, such as bracing, is used for less severe cases.
population_specificity: Patients with neuromuscular scoliosis (NMS), particularly those with cerebral palsy (CP) or Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of rosehip powder on knee joint biomechanics during walking in individuals with knee-related walking limitations.
results_summary: Rosehip powder significantly improved knee joint moments and flexion during walking compared to placebo, with statistically significant differences in the resultant knee moment and sagittal plane moments.
population_specificity: Individuals with self-reported knee-related walking limitations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the dietary habits of professional weightlifters and race walkers, as well as physical education students, to assess nutritional adequacy and differences.
results_summary: Race walkers consumed higher calorie diets relative to body mass, while weightlifters showed no significant dietary differences compared to other groups. All groups had inappropriate intakes of protein, fat, and carbohydrates, and race walkers exceeded recommended vitamin and mineral levels due to aggressive supplementation.
population_specificity: 12 weightlifters, 12 race walkers, and 12 physical education students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine acute metabolic and cardiovascular responses to a thermogenic nutritional supplement during and after walking.
results_summary: The supplement increased energy expenditure and VO2 during walking and postexercise, but had no significant effects on respiratory exchange ratio, heart rate, perceived exertion, or blood pressure.
population_specificity: 21 men (mean age 23.5 ± 2.6 years, BMI 26.0 ± 2.4 kg/m²).
study_duration: Acute (single session with 60 minutes of walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether regular aerobic training (cycling) and postexercise protein-carbohydrate supplementation improved fitness, walking speed, and other health metrics in patients with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD).
results_summary: The study found that 12 weeks of endurance training improved fitness, workload, and walking speed in FSHD patients, with no additional benefits from protein-carbohydrate supplementation. Muscle strength and daily activity levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Untrained men and women (ages 19-65) with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD).
effective_dosage: 36 sessions of 30-minute cycle-ergometer training, with postexercise protein-carbohydrate or placebo beverage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplemented essential amino acids (EAAs) could improve exercise intolerance in elderly patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that EAA supplementation (8 g/d) improved exercise capacity in CHF patients (18.7%-23% increase in bicycle test, 12%-22% in 6-minute walking test) and physical autonomy in COPD patients (78.6% increase in steps/day). Additionally, resting plasma lactate levels decreased (25% in CHF, 23% in COPD), and tissue insulin sensitivity improved in CHF patients (16% HOMA index).
population_specificity: Elderly patients with CHF or COPD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in cardiovascular lifestyle behaviors, including walking frequency, in hypercholesterolemic patients consuming phytosterol-supplemented yoghurt over 4 months.
results_summary: The frequency of walking (>30 min) significantly increased from 59.3% to 78.3% (p < 0.0001), alongside improvements in lipid profiles and anthropometric measures. These changes were linked to healthier lifestyles and better adherence to the dietary intervention.
population_specificity: Hypercholesterolemic patients (54.8% women, average age 56.2 years) from general practices in France and Spain.
effective_dosage: Daily consumption of phytosterol-supplemented yoghurt (specific amount not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of GH augmentation (including GHRH agonists like tesamorelin) for anti-aging effects, focusing on improvements in physical function, body composition, and cognitive outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that GH supplementation in older men increased lean mass and reduced fat mass but showed little evidence of improving muscle strength, physical performance (e.g., walking speed), or quality of life. Tesamorelin improved GH pulsatility, reduced visceral fat and triglycerides, and enhanced cognitive function.
population_specificity: Older men (women were noted to be more resistant to treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence and functional impact of bilateral vestibular hypofunction (BVH) on walking and daily activities in the US adult population.
results_summary: The study found that BVH significantly impacts walking, with 58% of affected individuals reporting difficulties in daily activities and a 31-fold increased risk of falls; 25% reported recent fall-related injuries.
population_specificity: US adults (N = 21,782) from the 2008 Balance and Dizziness Supplement to the National Health Interview Survey.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether high-dose, intermittent cholecalciferol (vitamin D) supplementation improves blood pressure and vascular health markers, including walking distance, in older patients with isolated systolic hypertension.
results_summary: The study found no significant treatment effect on walking distance or any of the secondary outcomes, including blood pressure, arterial stiffness, endothelial function, cholesterol level, and glucose level. Vitamin D supplementation did not demonstrate efficacy in improving these measures.
population_specificity: Patients aged 70 years and older with isolated systolic hypertension and baseline 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels less than 30 ng/mL.
effective_dosage: 100,000 U of oral cholecalciferol every 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistance exercise combined with essential amino acid supplementation improves psoas major muscle hypertrophy and walking ability in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the 6-month training program led to significant psoas major muscle hypertrophy in all groups, with dose-dependent (though not statistically significant) effects from amino acid supplementation. Groups receiving amino acids (A3 and A6) showed improvements in 10-meter walk tests, while only the higher-dose group (A6) improved in the 6-minute walk test.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly individuals
effective_dosage: 3.0 g (A3) and 6.0 g (A6) of essential amino acid supplementation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify effective fall-preventive intervention programs, including physical training like walking, for community-dwelling elderly.
results_summary: The study found that structured fall-preventive programs, particularly those involving physical training, significantly reduce fall risk in the elderly. Additional effective strategies included home hazard modification, antislip shoe devices, medication adjustment, and vitamin D supplementation.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly, especially high-risk groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a single bout of controlled walking on markers of oxidation, inflammation, and skin capillary microcirculation in obese pre-menopausal women.
results_summary: A single bout of moderate walking significantly increased blood flow and relative hemoglobin concentration, with a trend toward increased oxygen saturation of hemoglobin. These improvements were independent of supplementation.
population_specificity: Forty-two obese pre-menopausal women (non-smokers, BMI 34.5 ± 3.8 kg/m², age 41 ± 5 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (single bout of 30-minute treadmill walking at 70% of VO2max).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy and adverse effects of levobupivacaine administered via caudal block versus dorsal penile nerve block (DPNB) in pediatric patients post-circumcision, including its impact on walking.
results_summary: The study found that caudal block with levobupivacaine delayed the time to first walking compared to DPNB, with a significant increase in motor block incidence in the caudal group. Walking was assessed as part of postoperative recovery metrics.
population_specificity: 60 boys aged 2-10 years undergoing circumcision.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether post-exercise macronutrient supplementation enhances increases in skeletal muscle mass and strength during home-based interval walking training in middle-aged and older women.
results_summary: The study found that post-exercise macronutrient supplementation significantly increased hamstring muscle tissue area (2.8% vs -1.0%) and isometric knee flexion force (16.3% vs 6.5%) compared to walking alone. These results suggest that supplementation partially enhances the benefits of interval walking training.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged and older women (41-78 years).
effective_dosage: Post-exercise macronutrient supplementation (7.6 g protein, 32.5 g carbohydrate, and 4.4 g fat) after each walking session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of nutritional support on anthropometric measures, pulmonary function, respiratory and peripheral muscle strength, endurance, functional exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life in COPD patients, particularly those who are malnourished.
results_summary: The study found moderate-quality evidence that nutritional supplementation promotes significant weight gain, especially in malnourished COPD patients, along with improvements in fat-free mass, fat mass, respiratory muscle strength, and six-minute walk distance. However, adequately nourished patients showed less response to supplementation, and no significant differences were found in some measures like triceps skinfold thickness or forced expiratory volume.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), particularly those who are malnourished or undernourished.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effect of the herbal formulation LI85008F on weight loss in obese human subjects, with participants adhering to a calorie-controlled diet and a walking regimen.
results_summary: The study found that LI85008F supplementation led to significant reductions in body weight, BMI, fasting blood glucose, LDL, LDL/HDL ratio, and triglycerides, along with increased serum adiponectin levels. No major adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (BMI 30-40 kg/m², ages 27-50, 29.3% male, 70.7% female).
effective_dosage: 900 mg/day of LI85008F in three divided doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a trimodal prehabilitation program (including moderate exercise, nutritional counseling, protein supplementation, and anxiety reduction) improved postoperative functional recovery, specifically walking capacity, in patients undergoing colorectal cancer resections.
results_summary: The prehabilitation program significantly improved functional walking capacity preoperatively and postoperatively, with prehabilitated patients showing better recovery (81% vs. 40% in controls) and higher physical activity levels. No differences were observed in complication rates or hospital stay length.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal cancer resections.
effective_dosage: Not specified (moderate exercise program combined with nutritional counseling, protein supplementation, and anxiety reduction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the self-administered BNI question could effectively distinguish between gait and balance issues in Parkinson's disease patients compared to the MDS-UPDRS.
